subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quickscript letters
msgSnippet: Hi Benjamin, I m a Brit and a fan of dialect. I gather that the idea is to agree a dialect of Engish to use but I reckon that is going to be hard to do; so
messageBody:
Hi Benjamin,
I'm a Brit and a fan of dialect. I gather that the idea is to agree a
dialect of Engish to use but I reckon that is going to be hard to do; so
many folk like yourself don't want to have to learn a new accent to
write with! I have corresponded QS-wise with people from the USA and New
Zealand who just write as they talk. It takes a little getting used to
but in principle is no different to speech, in fact I liked 'hearing'
their accents as I read. More human somehow....
-Andii

On Fri, 2005-10-28 at 12:04 -0500, Benjamin J. Bruce wrote:
> Hello,
>
> I just found out about Quickscript a month or two ago, and I am
> learning how to write in it. I'm a big fan of alternate writing
> systems, and I've invented and memorized several myself. I even tried
> to learn Gregg shorthand once, but finally gave up since it wasn't
> phonemic. Anyway, in the process of learning Quickscript, I've come
> across a question about it:
> 1. I see there are three letters, which are described as having
> the sounds of "calm", "haul", and " on", respectively. In my
> dialect of English (I live in Texas), all three of these are
> pronounced the same! For example, I pronounce the words
> "caught" and "cot" with the same vowel sound as is in "awe".
> How should I do this in Quickscript? I don't really want to
> memorise how other people pronounce certain words in order to
> spell Quickscript right.
> I think Quickscript looks like a really great alphabet, and I'm
> looking forward to being able to read and wright it. It would be
> great if it were more widely used, but it's kind of like trying to
> teach Esperanto to everyone in the world; English is so widespread, it
> would have to be an international thing.
>
> Anyway, please let me know if any of y'all can help me with this,
> and I'll keep working on it!
>
> Thanks.
>
> -Benjamin Bruce
>
>

Hi Benjamin,
I'm a Brit and a fan of dialect. I gather that the idea is to agree a
dialect of Engish to use but I reckon that is going to be hard to do; so
many folk like yourself don't want to have to learn a new accent to
write with! I have corresponded QS-wise with people from the USA and New
Zealand who just write as they talk. It takes a little getting used to
but in principle is no different to speech, in fact I liked 'hearing'
their accents as I read. More human somehow....
-Andii

On Fri, 2005-10-28 at 12:04 -0500, Benjamin J. Bruce wrote:
> Hello,
> 
>    I just found out about Quickscript a month or two ago, and I am
> learning how to write in it.  I'm a big fan of alternate writing
> systems, and I've invented and memorized several myself.  I even tried
> to learn Gregg shorthand once, but finally gave up since it wasn't
> phonemic.  Anyway, in the process of learning Quickscript, I've come
> across a question about it:
>      1. I see there are three letters, which are described as having
>         the sounds of "calm", "haul", and " on", respectively.  In my
>         dialect of English (I live in Texas), all three of these are
>         pronounced the same!  For example, I pronounce the words
>         "caught" and "cot" with the same vowel sound as is in "awe".
>         How should I do this in Quickscript?  I don't really want to
>         memorise how other people pronounce certain words in order to
>         spell Quickscript right.
>    I think Quickscript looks like a really great alphabet, and I'm
> looking forward to being able to read and wright it.  It would be
> great if it were more widely used, but it's kind of like trying to
> teach Esperanto to everyone in the world; English is so widespread, it
> would have to be an international thing.
> 
>    Anyway, please let me know if any of y'all can help me with this,
> and I'll keep working on it!
> 
>    Thanks.
> 
> -Benjamin Bruce
